After which, Ms. HUCKSTONE'K popular Comedy of

01IV l i i i i a i AlAA JElB
As the Coinedj of * MARRIED L I F E * attempted to illustrate a few of
the humour*- of the State Matrimonial, and intercut an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers w h a t e v e r ; the author of *S1 M€*LE LIFE *
in going to the opposite extreme and making hi« Characters • LOVERS
ALL,* hopes to he equally successful In pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has Its
hlelserings as well as the most loyal one of » The United States.*

Mr. John Niggle,

AIM- which, M.. BDCKSTOHE'S po-ultr Conn-dy «r

SINGLE LIFE.

As the Comedy of • M ARRIEII L I F E * attempted to illustrate a few of
the humour* of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever ; the author of •SIN4.LE! LIFE*
in going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters * LOVERS
ALL,* hopes to he equally successful in pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has its
bickerings as well as the most loyal one of • The United States.'

" T h | new comedy o f ' Money f wa- a happy and triumphant
answer to all that eloquence and ingenuity which have so long
maintained the hopelessness of expecting, in the present day,
anything like a revival of t h e spirit of the old English comedy
of manners and character. Trie comic muae must not y e t
d e s p a i r ; and we must not j e t flatter ourselves that we have
been thoroughly taught, by either gaiet) or gravity, the actor
or the schoolmaster. Sir Edward Bttlwer has shown how rich
are still the comic materials of t h e time, to a shfewd and exact
o b s e r v e r ; a n d that fashionable life has nothing left of its
egotism and hollowness since m> Lord Foppmgton
' sapped
his vitals.' It. Would b e impossible to praise too highly t h e
appointments of this comedy, and the manner in which it h a s
been placed on the stage. Everything was real, and nothing
less splendid than it should have been
The house of Evelyn
w a s a perfect picture of g o r g e o u s taste ; and t h e club scene,
with its crowds of well-dressed members and niceties of a r -angemetit
and turmture, would n o doubt h e recognised by
iriany among the audience."— Mornvig Ckroniiet,

Dee. 9.
" ' Monty !' was produced a t this theatre last night, with all
t h e aids of entirely new scenery, dresses, furniture, and appurtenances. If is but fair to notice t h . magnificent manner in
which Mr. W e b s t e r has put it on the stage. N e w furniture did
a o t alone appear in the play-bills ; had t h e most fashionable
.pholsterer been consulted, taste and splendour could not have
shone more conspicuously. T h e comedy was justly most s u c cessful. T h e dialogue is well suited to each person in t h e
drama. T h e r e i» no double plot to perplex, no inharmonious—
no incongruous shifting of time or p l a c e ; t h e whole is
finely kept t o g e t h e r , ihe main story being constantly before t h e
mind's eye. At the full of the curtain the a p p l a u s e was loud,
long-continued, and general
The comedy will doubtless hear
t h e management well up till the close of the season. '—Mnrning

" Sir Edward Lyttoa Bulwer's comedy is certainly the best
modern couirtdy t i n t has been produced for many years. Altogether it is one of very great m e r i t ; the interest t h r o u g h o u t is
most powerfully sustained; from t h e first act to the last, t h e
attention is constantly excited by some new incident. T h e
l a n g u a g e loo is extremely good ; it abounds in point, and which
falling olf without any seeming effect, tells with t h e best effect.
W e need scan e!\ sue that t h e play was in the highest degree
successful, and that tt will rival t h e Love Chase in its career.
With regard to the acting, w e have also to speak in terms of
high praisT h e scenery i s beautifully painted, a n d every
scene is laid out to give an exact representation of an e l e g a n t
room with all its h n n r i c * and extravagant a p p e n d a g e s . T h .
interior ol Orockford's Club is admirably done, a n d elicited
much applause f om its splendour."—Magnet, Dec. 14,
' Sir E. L. Biilsver's play of ' Money / ' was produced at this
theatre, with i i ast and in a style that did g r e a t credit to t h e
theatre. T h e g e n u i n e power of this performance b e l o n g s t o
an ancient, recognised, a n d h i g h order of the comic. T h .
power of seizing t h e c h a r a c t e r s and manners of the-age, a n d
holding the mirror u p lo society ; and that, too, after it has so
long been asserted that the p r o g r e s s of cirih-atioa had d e stroyed t h e materials for such a purpose. Sir Edward Lyttoa
Bulwer has shown us, on the contrary, that life is y e t full of
varieties sufficient!! marked for t h . most .ff.ctive awes of t h .
drama,—that the.e a r e men, distinct from t h e s u r r o u n r l t a f
herd, whose individualities a r e admirably fit for t h e stagey-.and that there n-« w a n e s in the commonest streets t h r o u g h
which wo dail\ walk, as amusine and rich a s w e r e offered t o
Congrev-e, or F a n j u h a r , or a a y of the elder dramatists, b e f o r .
t h e social system was macadamised into a rather general leveL
His figures stand out well from the mass. A b ^ i e r acting, or
better acted p1 i h a t not been b r o u g h t out in our time, and we
remember
jaAn fiull.
I t often, by its sparkling allusions,
recalled Yht School for Scandal
t o our minds, a n d t h e drop
scene certainly !»!l upon every a c t amidst bursts of applause t o
the skill d i s p i a v I m t h e construction of these pauses, g i v i n g
uach a scenic Hraol and interest which couidnot b e improved.
—I,itrrarii Gaz> He. Saturday,

ttudienca geensed delighted equally with the fun and t h e sentiment. It is pointed and clever. Some bustling scenes of
broad f a r e , are intermixed with a due quantity of sentimental
s p . . o a a » ( and the stage situations a r e as effectively l u d i e r . u a
